questions.question: Which level of organisation is exhibited by sponges?
questions.explanation: In sponges, the cells are arranged as loose cell aggregates, i.e., they exhibit cellular level of organisation. Some division of labour occurs among the cells. (NCERT Page 37)

questions.question: Tissue level of organisation is first seen in:
questions.explanation: In coelenterates, cells performing the same function are arranged into tissues, hence is called tissue level of organisation. (NCERT Page 37)

questions.question: Organ level of organisation is first exhibited by:
questions.explanation: Organ level of organisation is exhibited by members of Platyhelminthes and other higher phyla where tissues are grouped together to form organs. (NCERT Page 37)

questions.question: An incomplete digestive system has:
options: Only a single opening that serves as both mouth and anus
questions.explanation: In Platyhelminthes, the digestive system has only a single opening that serves as both mouth and anus, hence called incomplete. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: In open type circulatory system:
options: Blood is pumped out and cells are directly bathed in it
questions.explanation: In open type circulatory system, blood is pumped out of the heart and the cells and tissues are directly bathed in it. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: Which animals are mostly asymmetrical?
questions.explanation: Sponges are mostly asymmetrical, i.e., any plane that passes through the centre does not divide them into equal halves. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: Radial symmetry is found in:
questions.explanation: Radial symmetry, where any plane passing through the central axis divides the organism into two identical halves, is found in coelenterates, ctenophores and echinoderms. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: Bilateral symmetry is exhibited by:
questions.explanation: Animals like annelids, arthropods, etc., where body can be divided into identical left and right halves in only one plane, exhibit bilateral symmetry. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: Diploblastic animals have:
options: Two germ layers - ectoderm and endoderm
questions.explanation: Animals in which cells are arranged in two embryonic layers, an external ectoderm and an internal endoderm, are called diploblastic animals, e.g., coelenterates. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: The undifferentiated layer present between ectoderm and endoderm in diploblastic animals is:
questions.explanation: In diploblastic animals, an undifferentiated layer called mesoglea is present in between the ectoderm and endoderm. (NCERT Page 38)

questions.question: Triploblastic animals have mesoderm between:
questions.explanation: Animals having a third germinal layer, mesoderm, in between the ectoderm and endoderm are called triploblastic animals. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: The body cavity lined by mesoderm is called:
questions.explanation: The body cavity which is lined by mesoderm is called coelom. Animals possessing coelom are called coelomates. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Pseudocoelomates are:
questions.explanation: In pseudocoelomates, the body cavity is not lined by mesoderm; instead mesoderm is present as scattered pouches. E.g., Aschelminthes. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Acoelomates are animals in which:
options: Body cavity is lined by mesoderm
questions.explanation: The animals in which body cavity is absent are called acoelomates, e.g., platyhelminthes. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Metameric segmentation is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: In earthworm, the body shows metameric segmentation (serial repetition of at least some organs) and the phenomenon is known as metamerism. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Notochord is derived from:
questions.explanation: Notochord is a mesodermally derived rod-like structure formed on the dorsal side during embryonic development in some animals. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Non-chordates include:
questions.explanation: Animals which do not form notochord are called non-chordates, e.g., porifera to echinoderms. (NCERT Page 39)

questions.question: Sponges have a water transport system through which water enters via:
questions.explanation: Water enters through minute pores (ostia) in the body wall into a central cavity, spongocoel, from where it goes out through the osculum. (NCERT Page 40)

questions.question: Choanocytes or collar cells are found in:
questions.explanation: Choanocytes or collar cells line the spongocoel and the canals in sponges. (NCERT Page 40)

questions.question: The skeleton of sponges is made up of:
questions.explanation: The body of sponges is supported by a skeleton made up of spicules or spongin fibres. (NCERT Page 40)

questions.question: Sponges are:
questions.explanation: Sexes are not separate (hermaphrodite) in sponges, i.e., eggs and sperms are produced by the same individual. (NCERT Page 40)

questions.question: Spongilla is a:
questions.explanation: Spongilla is a fresh water sponge. Sycon and Euspongia (Bath sponge) are other examples of Porifera. (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: Cnidoblasts containing nematocysts are found in:
questions.explanation: The name cnidaria is derived from cnidoblasts or cnidocytes which contain the stinging capsules or nematocysts present on tentacles and body. (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: Cnidoblasts are used for:
options: Anchorage, defense and capture of prey
questions.explanation: Cnidoblasts are used for anchorage, defense and for the capture of prey. (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: The two basic body forms in cnidarians are:
questions.explanation: Cnidarians exhibit two basic body forms - polyp (sessile, cylindrical) and medusa (umbrella-shaped, free-swimming). (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: Alternation of generation (Metagenesis) is seen in:
questions.explanation: Cnidarians which exist in both polyp and medusa forms exhibit alternation of generations (Metagenesis), e.g., Obelia. (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: Aurelia is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Aurelia is umbrella-shaped and free-swimming, commonly called jelly fish. It represents the medusa form. (NCERT Page 41)

questions.question: Ctenophores are commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Ctenophores are commonly known as sea walnuts or comb jellies. They are exclusively marine and radially symmetrical. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: Comb plates help in:
questions.explanation: The body of ctenophores bears eight external rows of ciliated comb plates, which help in locomotion. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: Bioluminescence is well-marked in:
questions.explanation: Bioluminescence (the property of a living organism to emit light) is well-marked in ctenophores. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: Flatworms belong to phylum:
questions.explanation: Platyhelminthes have dorso-ventrally flattened body, hence are called flatworms. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: Flame cells help in:
questions.explanation: Specialised cells called flame cells help in osmoregulation and excretion in flatworms. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: High regeneration capacity is possessed by:
questions.explanation: Some members like Planaria possess high regeneration capacity. (NCERT Page 42)

questions.question: Roundworms belong to phylum:
questions.explanation: The body of aschelminthes is circular in cross-section, hence the name roundworms. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: In Aschelminthes, sexes are:
questions.explanation: Sexes are separate (dioecious), i.e., males and females are distinct in Aschelminthes. Often females are longer than males. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: Wuchereria causes:
questions.explanation: Wuchereria is the filaria worm that causes filariasis. It belongs to Aschelminthes. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: The phylum name Annelida is derived from:
questions.explanation: The body surface of annelids is distinctly marked out into segments or metameres, hence the phylum name Annelida (Latin, annulus: little ring). (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: Parapodia are lateral appendages found in:
questions.explanation: Aquatic annelids like Nereis possess lateral appendages, parapodia, which help in swimming. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: Nephridia help in:
questions.explanation: Nephridia (sing. nephridium) help in osmoregulation and excretion in annelids. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: Annelids have which type of circulatory system?
questions.explanation: A closed circulatory system is present in annelids. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: Earthworms and leeches are:
questions.explanation: Nereis, an aquatic form, is dioecious, but earthworms and leeches are monoecious. (NCERT Page 43)

questions.question: The largest phylum of Animalia is:
questions.explanation: Arthropoda is the largest phylum of Animalia which includes insects. Over two-thirds of all named species on earth are arthropods. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: The body of arthropods is covered by:
questions.explanation: The body of arthropods is covered by chitinous exoskeleton. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: Malpighian tubules are excretory organs of:
questions.explanation: Excretion in arthropods takes place through malpighian tubules. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: Limulus is called:
questions.explanation: Limulus (King crab) is called a living fossil among arthropods. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: Arthropods have which type of circulatory system?
questions.explanation: Circulatory system in arthropods is of open type. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: The second largest animal phylum is:
questions.explanation: Mollusca is the second largest animal phylum. They are terrestrial or aquatic. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: Radula is a file-like rasping organ found in:
questions.explanation: The mouth of molluscs contains a file-like rasping organ for feeding, called radula. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: The soft spongy layer of skin forming mantle in molluscs covers:
questions.explanation: A soft and spongy layer of skin forms a mantle over the visceral hump in molluscs. (NCERT Page 44)

questions.question: Octopus is also known as:
questions.explanation: Octopus is commonly known as Devil fish. It belongs to phylum Mollusca. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: The name Echinodermata means:
questions.explanation: Echinoderms have an endoskeleton of calcareous ossicles and, hence, the name Echinodermata (Spiny bodied). (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: The most distinctive feature of echinoderms is:
questions.explanation: The most distinctive feature of echinoderms is the presence of water vascular system which helps in locomotion, capture and transport of food and respiration. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: Adult echinoderms are:
questions.explanation: Adult echinoderms are radially symmetrical but larvae are bilaterally symmetrical. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: Asterias is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Asterias is commonly called star fish. It belongs to Echinodermata. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: Hemichordates have a rudimentary structure in collar region called:
questions.explanation: Hemichordates have a rudimentary structure in the collar region called stomochord, similar to notochord. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: The body of Balanoglossus is composed of:
questions.explanation: The body of hemichordates is cylindrical and composed of an anterior proboscis, a collar and a long trunk. (NCERT Page 45)

questions.question: Chordates are characterized by:
options: Notochord, ventral nerve cord and gill slits
Notochord, dorsal hollow nerve cord and pharyngeal gill slits
questions.explanation: Animals of phylum Chordata are characterized by the presence of a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord and paired pharyngeal gill slits. (NCERT Page 45-46)

questions.question: In chordates, the heart is:
questions.explanation: In chordates, heart is ventral, whereas in non-chordates heart is dorsal (if present). (NCERT Table 4.1, Page 46)

questions.question: Protochordates include:
questions.explanation: Subphyla Urochordata and Cephalochordata are often referred to as protochordates and are exclusively marine. (NCERT Page 46)

questions.question: In Urochordata, notochord is present in:
questions.explanation: In Urochordata, notochord is present only in larval tail, while in Cephalochordata, it extends from head to tail and persists throughout life. (NCERT Page 46)

questions.question: Cyclostomes have:
options: Sucking and circular mouth without jaws
questions.explanation: Cyclostomes have a sucking and circular mouth without jaws. They are ectoparasites on some fishes. (NCERT Page 47)

questions.question: Chondrichthyes have:
questions.explanation: Chondrichthyes are marine animals with streamlined body and have cartilaginous endoskeleton. (NCERT Page 47)

questions.question: Placoid scales are found in:
questions.explanation: The skin of Chondrichthyes is tough, containing minute placoid scales. Teeth are modified placoid scales. (NCERT Page 47)

questions.question: Chondrichthyes lack air bladder, hence they:
options: Have to swim constantly to avoid sinking
questions.explanation: Due to the absence of air bladder, Chondrichthyes have to swim constantly to avoid sinking. (NCERT Page 47)

questions.question: Electric organs are present in:
questions.explanation: Some Chondrichthyes have electric organs (e.g., Torpedo) and some possess poison sting (e.g., Trygon). (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: In bony fishes, gills are covered by:
questions.explanation: Osteichthyes have four pairs of gills which are covered by an operculum on each side. (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: Air bladder in bony fishes helps in:
questions.explanation: Air bladder is present in Osteichthyes which regulates buoyancy. (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: Hippocampus is commonly called:
questions.explanation: Hippocampus is commonly called Sea horse. It is a marine bony fish. (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: Amphibians have a heart with:
questions.explanation: The heart in amphibians is three-chambered (two auricles and one ventricle). (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: The common chamber where alimentary canal, urinary and reproductive tracts open is called:
questions.explanation: Alimentary canal, urinary and reproductive tracts open into a common chamber called cloaca which opens to the exterior. (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: Ichthyophis is a:
questions.explanation: Ichthyophis is a limbless amphibian. Other examples include Bufo (Toad), Rana (Frog), Salamandra. (NCERT Page 48)

questions.question: The skin of reptiles is:
questions.explanation: Reptiles are mostly terrestrial and their body is covered by dry and cornified skin, epidermal scales or scutes. (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: Four-chambered heart is found in:
questions.explanation: Heart is usually three-chambered in reptiles, but four-chambered in crocodiles. (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: Which of the following is a poisonous snake?
questions.explanation: Poisonous snakes include Naja (Cobra), Bangarus (Krait), Vipera (Viper). (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: The characteristic feature of Aves is:
questions.explanation: The characteristic features of Aves (birds) are the presence of feathers and forelimbs modified into wings. (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: The long bones in birds are hollow with air cavities called:
questions.explanation: Endoskeleton in birds is fully ossified (bony) and the long bones are hollow with air cavities (pneumatic). (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: Birds are:
questions.explanation: Birds are warm-blooded (homoiothermous) animals, i.e., they can maintain a constant body temperature. (NCERT Page 49)

questions.question: Struthio is commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Struthio is the ostrich, a flightless bird. (NCERT Page 50)

questions.question: The most unique characteristic of mammals is:
questions.explanation: The most unique mammalian characteristic is the presence of milk producing glands (mammary glands) by which young ones are nourished. (NCERT Page 50)

questions.question: External ears or pinnae are present in:
questions.explanation: External ears or pinnae are present in mammals. Different types of teeth are present in the jaw. (NCERT Page 51)

questions.question: Ornithorhynchus (Platypus) is:
questions.explanation: Ornithorhynchus (Platypus) is an oviparous (egg-laying) mammal. Most other mammals are viviparous. (NCERT Page 51)

questions.question: Balaenoptera is the:
questions.explanation: Balaenoptera is the Blue whale. Other examples include Delphinus (Common dolphin), Macropus (Kangaroo). (NCERT Page 51)
